episodeTitle: Execution Order Issued! Break Through the Encircling Walls!
episodeTitleJapanese: 処刑執行命令下る 包囲壁を突破せよ！
episodeTitleRomaji: Shokei Shikkō Shirei Kudaru - Hōiheki o Toppaseyo!
description: Akainu's devastating Meteor Volcano attack destroys the Whitebeard Pirates' ships and melts the ice into boiling water, trapping the pirates between cannons and Pacifistas. As Sengoku orders Ace's immediate execution, Little Oars Jr. regains consciousness. Jinbe uses his Fish-Man Karate to launch Luffy over the encircling wall on a ship's mast, leading to a dramatic confrontation with the three admirals. Luffy debuts his Gomu Gomu no Stamp Gatling technique to shatter the frozen mast, while Whitebeard prepares to play his trump card to turn the tide of battle.

events.title: Akainu's Meteor Volcano Devastates the Pirate Fleet
events.description: Admiral Akainu unleashes his devastating Ryūsei Kazan (Meteor Volcano) attack, launching massive magma fists into the sky that rain down on the battlefield. The attack melts nearly all the ice in Marineford Bay and destroys the Whitebeard Pirates' ships, including the Moby Dick. The melted ice becomes boiling water, trapping the pirates.
events.significance: This attack dramatically shifts the battle in the Marines' favor by eliminating the pirates' escape routes and trapping them between the encircling walls, cannons, and Pacifistas. It demonstrates Akainu's ruthless efficiency and overwhelming destructive power.

events.title: Sengoku Orders Ace's Immediate Execution
events.description: With the Whitebeard Pirates trapped and unable to advance, Fleet Admiral Sengoku sees the perfect opportunity and orders the immediate execution of Portgas D. Ace. The executioners prepare to carry out the sentence as the pirates struggle to break through the encircling walls.
events.significance: This is a critical turning point that raises the stakes to maximum tension. The execution order pushes Luffy and the Whitebeard Pirates into desperate action, setting up the climactic moments of the arc. It shows Sengoku's tactical decisiveness in exploiting the advantage created by Akainu's attack.

events.title: Sabaody Archipelago Reacts to Broadcast Interruption
events.description: At Sabaody Archipelago, the spectators watching the battle broadcast grow impatient as the transmission cuts off intermittently. The Eleven Supernovas, including Eustass Kid, Trafalgar Law, and Capone Bege, discuss the unfolding events. Kid's crew decides to leave since they believe 'the show is over,' while others debate whether Whitebeard truly sold out his allies.
events.significance: This scene provides a global perspective on the Marineford War, showing how the world is watching this historic battle. It establishes the Supernovas as witnesses to this pivotal moment and foreshadows their future roles in the story. The debate about Whitebeard's alleged betrayal shows how misinformation spreads during war.

quotes.text: In the anime, it was Law who commented on how ridiculous the belief that Whitebeard sold out his allies was, while in the manga it was Bege.
quotes.speaker: Trafalgar Law (anime) / Capone Bege (manga)
quotes.context: Discussing the misinformation about Whitebeard during the battle

events.title: Little Oars Jr. Regains Consciousness
events.description: Just when hope seems lost for the Whitebeard Pirates, Little Oars Jr. regains consciousness after being gravely wounded earlier in the battle. The pirates rejoice at seeing their massive ally wake up. Whitebeard instructs Oars to hold his ground and help with a decisive tactic.
events.significance: Oars Jr.'s return provides a crucial turning point and emotional boost for the pirates. His body blocking the hole in the encircling wall becomes a vital strategic element. This moment demonstrates the indomitable spirit of Whitebeard's crew and their refusal to give up even when facing overwhelming odds.

events.title: Jinbe Launches Luffy Over the Wall with Fish-Man Karate
events.description: Using his mastery of Fish-Man Karate, Jinbe creates a powerful water column from the boiling water in the bay. He launches Luffy high into the air on a ship's mast, sending him over the massive encircling wall directly toward the execution platform. This demonstrates the advanced techniques of Fish-Man Karate in manipulating water even in extreme conditions.
events.significance: This is a pivotal moment that allows Luffy to bypass the Marines' defensive perimeter and reach the inner plaza. It showcases Jinbe's incredible power and his commitment to helping Luffy save Ace. The technique demonstrates why Fish-Men are so formidable in maritime combat.

events.title: Luffy Confronts the Three Admirals
events.description: Luffy lands in the plaza directly in front of the three Marine Admirals - Akainu, Kizaru, and Aokiji. The admirals acknowledge Luffy's strength and tenacity for making it this far. This is the first time Luffy has faced all three admirals simultaneously, representing the ultimate test of his determination to save Ace.
events.significance: This is an iconic moment in the Marineford Arc where Luffy fearlessly challenges the three most powerful fighters in the Marine forces. It demonstrates Luffy's unwavering resolve to save his brother regardless of the overwhelming odds. The admirals' comments show their recognition of the Straw Hat captain as a genuine threat.

events.title: Gomu Gomu no Stamp Gatling Debut
events.description: When Admiral Aokiji freezes the mast Luffy is riding, Luffy responds by using a new technique: Gomu Gomu no Stamp Gatling. Similar to Gomu Gomu no Stamp but with multiple rapid kicks, Luffy shatters the frozen mast and sends shards of ice flying toward the three admirals.
events.significance: This marks the first appearance of the Gomu Gomu no Stamp Gatling technique in the series. While the admirals are ultimately unfazed by the attack, it demonstrates Luffy's creativity in adapting his abilities during battle and his refusal to back down even when facing impossible odds. The technique shows the evolution of Luffy's fighting style.

events.title: Kizaru Repels Luffy's Attack
events.description: After Luffy's Stamp Gatling shatters the frozen mast, Admiral Kizaru easily pushes Luffy back with a light-speed kick, demonstrating the vast power gap between Luffy and the admirals. Despite his determination, Luffy is clearly outmatched by the admirals' overwhelming strength.
events.significance: This moment reinforces the reality that Luffy, despite his growth, is still not at the level to fight admirals. It shows that courage and determination alone cannot overcome such a vast difference in power, adding tension to his mission to save Ace.

events.title: Whitebeard Prepares His Trump Card
events.description: Observing Luffy's reckless bravery and noting how similar it is to Ace's personality, Whitebeard commands Jozu and Oars Jr. to prepare for their trump card strategy. He has a hidden submarine ship coated and ready beneath the ice that will allow his forces to break through to the plaza.
events.significance: This sets up Whitebeard's tactical counterattack that will shift the momentum back toward the pirates. It shows Whitebeard's strategic planning and his determination to save Ace. The comparison between Luffy and Ace also reinforces the bond between the two brothers and why Whitebeard respects Luffy's efforts.

quotes.text: That brat... he's just like Ace. Reckless to a fault.
quotes.speaker: Whitebeard
quotes.context: Commenting on Luffy's fearless charge toward the admirals

events.title: Pacifistas Attack the Pirates
events.description: The Pacifista units surround the Whitebeard Pirates who are trapped in the bay, attacking them with laser beams while they struggle in the boiling water created by Akainu's magma attack. The cyborg weapons work in coordination with the Marines' cannons to create a deadly crossfire.
events.significance: This demonstrates the effectiveness of the World Government's Pacifista weapons in large-scale warfare. Combined with Akainu's attack and the encircling walls, the Pacifistas create a nearly inescapable trap for the pirates.

quotes.text: That brat... he's just like Ace. Reckless to a fault.
quotes.speaker: Whitebeard
quotes.context: Commenting on Luffy's fearless charge toward the admirals

themes.description: The episode powerfully depicts the lengths to which people will go for those they love. Luffy's reckless charge toward the admirals mirrors Ace's own personality, highlighting their brotherhood. The Whitebeard Pirates' refusal to abandon Ace despite overwhelming odds demonstrates the strength of their familial bonds.
themes.symbolism: The encircling walls represent the seemingly insurmountable barriers between Luffy and saving his brother, yet he leaps over them anyway, symbolizing how love transcends all obstacles.

themes.description: The episode contrasts raw power with unwavering determination. The admirals possess overwhelming strength that easily repels Luffy's attacks, yet Luffy continues to push forward. Akainu's Meteor Volcano shows devastating force, but Little Oars Jr.'s revival demonstrates that willpower can overcome even near-fatal injuries.
themes.symbolism: The three admirals standing together represent an impossible wall of power, yet Luffy charges straight at them, symbolizing how determination can challenge even the most overwhelming odds.

themes.description: The Marines' tactical coordination - Akainu destroying the ships, the walls trapping the pirates, Pacifistas attacking, and Sengoku timing the execution perfectly - demonstrates the cold efficiency of military strategy. The World Government's machine of war operates with ruthless precision.
themes.symbolism: The boiling water created by melted ice represents how war transforms even neutral elements into weapons of death. The execution order represents the inevitable conclusion of military logic.

themes.description: Just when all seems lost, moments of hope emerge: Oars Jr. regains consciousness, Jinbe finds a way to launch Luffy over the wall, and Whitebeard reveals he has a trump card. These glimmers of hope keep the pirates fighting despite impossible odds.
themes.symbolism: Luffy being launched into the air represents hope rising above despair. His silhouette against the sky symbolizes a beacon of determination for all those fighting below.

characterSpotlights.development: Luffy demonstrates absolute fearlessness and determination, charging straight at the three admirals without hesitation. Despite being vastly outmatched, he refuses to back down from his mission to save Ace. His reckless bravery impresses even Whitebeard, who sees Ace's spirit in him.
keyActions: Rides a mast launched by Jinbe over the encircling wall
Debuts Gomu Gomu no Stamp Gatling technique
Continues pushing forward despite being repelled by Kizaru

characterSpotlights.development: Akainu demonstrates his ruthless efficiency and overwhelming power with the Meteor Volcano attack, single-handedly shifting the entire battle in the Marines' favor. His absolute justice ideology is reflected in his willingness to destroy everything to achieve victory.
keyActions: Destroys the Whitebeard Pirates' ships including the Moby Dick
Melts the ice into boiling water, trapping the pirates
Creates the conditions for Sengoku to order Ace's execution

characterSpotlights.development: Whitebeard shows his tactical mind by preparing a trump card while also displaying his emotional side by comparing Luffy to Ace. Despite the dire situation, he maintains his composure and continues to lead his forces with strategic precision.
keyActions: Commands Oars Jr. to hold his position
Orders Jozu to prepare the trump card
Plans the next phase of the battle
quotes: That brat... he's just like Ace. Reckless to a fault.

characterSpotlights.development: Jinbe proves instrumental in advancing Luffy's mission by using his Fish-Man Karate mastery to launch Luffy over the wall. His technical skill and quick thinking provide the key to bypassing the Marines' defenses.
keyActions: Uses Fish-Man Karate to manipulate the boiling water
Creates a water column to launch Luffy
Successfully sends Luffy over the encircling wall on a mast

characterSpotlights.development: Sengoku demonstrates his tactical acumen by recognizing the perfect moment to order Ace's execution. He capitalizes on Akainu's attack to eliminate any chance of the pirates mounting a successful rescue.
keyActions: Times the execution to maximize psychological impact

mangaDifferences.difference: In the manga, it was Capone Bege who commented on how ridiculous the belief that Whitebeard sold out his allies was. In the anime (Episode 474), this line was given to Trafalgar Law.
The anime adds extended scenes of the Pacifista units surrounding and attacking the pirates who tried to leave the bay, which was not as detailed in the manga.

Some of the Whitebeard Pirates commanders' lines and actions are redistributed to generic crew members in the anime. For example, Curiel's actions of firing at the encircling walls are shown with unnamed pirates.

trivia.fact: Episode 474 adapted Chapter 565 of the manga, titled 'Oars' Path,' covering pages 2-17.
This episode received a TV rating of 10.5% when it aired in Japan on November 7, 2010, ranking #1 in its time slot, showing the peak popularity of the Marineford Arc.
Gomu Gomu no Stamp Gatling made its debut in this episode and Chapter 565. It's a variation of the Stamp technique where Luffy performs multiple rapid kicks instead of a single stomp.

sources.title: Gomu Gomu no Mi/Techniques - One Piece Wiki

trivia.fact: The opening song 'One Day' by The ROOTLESS was considered more somber in tone compared to other One Piece openings, reflecting the dark and serious nature of the Marineford Arc.
This episode features one of the rare instances where Luffy directly confronts all three Marine Admirals simultaneously, showcasing the overwhelming power gap that existed at this point in the story.

At the time of this episode's original airing, the voice actor for Jinbe was still Daisuke Gori. He passed away in 2010, and was later replaced by Katsuhisa Hoki from episode 440 onwards in the Japanese version.
